Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: New safety steps were highlighted during the last briefing and everyone was asked to apply them consistently.
Story:
I had just moved into my new apartment, and the excitement of starting fresh was still buzzing in my chest. Wanting to make a good impression, I baked a small cake, hoping to share it with the neighbors if I bumped into them. That afternoon, as I stepped into the hallway, I saw Mrs. Kim from next door. She smiled warmly, and I offered her a slice. As we chatted, I noticed she wasn’t wearing a mask, and she reached out to shake my hand. 

Just yesterday, at my volunteer orientation, the coordinator had stressed the importance of following new safety protocols—no handshakes, masks on at all times, and maintaining distance, even outside the volunteer site. We were told to model these behaviors everywhere, not just while volunteering, to set an example and keep everyone safe. 

Standing there, cake in hand, I felt torn. I wanted to be the friendly, approachable neighbor, but I also felt the weight of my responsibility as a volunteer to uphold the safety guidelines. My heart pounded as I hesitated, caught between the warmth of neighborly kindness and the strict expectations of my volunteer role.
